SUMMARY: β-d-glucuronides repressor, UidR, is a transcriptional repressor. UidR negatively regulates its own synsis and represses transcription of uid operon, which is involved in transport and degradation of β-glucosides [3934044, 3079718, 6353163, 6276362, 776934]. This regulator is involved in degradation of sugar acids and is subject to catabolic repression in presence of glucose and at low levels of cyclic AMP. Although little is known about regulating mechanism of UidR, it has been shown to act as a repressor, binding to a putative inverted repeat sequence in a cooperative process with UxuR [6553163, 3079718, 2823062]. In 1986, Blanco et al. proposed that total repression of UidR is achieved in presence of UxuR, suggesting possibility that UidR and UxuR form a complex. Independently, each repressor binds to DNA separately [3079718, 3889544, 2823062].
